title-group.article-title: Effects of emergency preservation measures following excavation of mural paintings in Takamatsuzuka Tumulus

abstract.p: The deterioration of mural paintings in Takamatsuzuka Tumulus was not only caused by microorganisms like fungi, but also by spalling of lime plaster. Following excavation of mural paintings, the emergency preservation measures were applied to control the hygrothermal environment, however, without a visible success. To reduce the deterioration of mural paintings, one must reduce the frequency of wetting and drying cycles inside the chamber. Using climatic measurements, a numerical simulation of the effects of postexcavation preservation measures on hygrothermal behavior in the stone chambers of Takamatsuzuka Tumulus was performed. The results showed that the method of covering the exposed surface of the stone chamber with a certain thickness of soil will be more effective in limiting the temperature increases within the stone chamber and controlling dryness on the interior surfaces.

sec.title: History of conservation of Takamatsuzuka Tumulus
sec.p: Takamatsuzuka Tumulus is located in Asuka village, Nara Prefecture, Japan (as shown in Figure 1). In 1972, mural paintings in the stone chamber of this tumulus were discovered during excavation. Its origin is estimated as the period of the late 7th or early 8th century. Soon after, the tumulus was declared a historic site, and the mural paintings as a national treasure. After excavation, the degree of deterioration was documented in detail, and it was decided to preserve the site, with a temporary shelter erected on the south side of the tumulus to maintain the interior environment. Between 1974 and March 1976, the air conditioning facilities were constructed in the south side of the stone chamber, but fungi on the wall of the chamber were regularly observed between 1977 and 1984. Fungi occurred frequently thereafter, although to a lesser extent during the 1990s, and then reappeared in large quantities during autumn 2001.

caption.p: Position of Nara Prefecture and Takamatsuzuka Tumulus.

sec.p: With difficulty to preserve the mural paintings on-site, the stone chamber was dismantled (from October 2006 to August 2007) to restore the mural paintings in temporary restoration facilities.

sec.title: Influence of hygrothermal environment in stone chamber on deterioration of mural paintings
sec.p: The deterioration of mural paintings is generally caused by microorganisms such as fungi, detachment of lime plaster from the wall surface, salt deposition, and so on. Moreover, the calcium carbonate in lime plaster is soluble in water and reacts with carbon dioxide in air, furthering the chemical deterioration of painted murals.

The growth of fungi requires specific conditions, such as nourishment, water, oxygen, and appropriate temperature. As almost all organisms can nourish fungi, and oxygen exists everywhere among the pores of stone chambers, it is difficult to eliminate these two factors. Studies using the fungi and bacterium from Takamatsuzuka Tumulus showed that the growth rate of bacteria was directly proportional to temperature, and growth was observed even at about 5°C (Takatori et al., 2010). That is to say, although fungi grow slowly when the indoor temperature is low, it is difficult to prevent fungi growing by lowering the indoor temperature. In terms of moisture, fungi cannot grow at relative humidity (RH) lower than 60%, but moisture can also cause deterioration such as detachment of lime plaster. Condensation on wall surfaces can also accelerate fungal growth.

Detachment of lime plaster and salt effloresce on the surface of stone are classified as physical deterioration (however, salt efflorescence has not been confimed in Takamatsuzuka Tumulus). Although the deterioration of the lime plaster is caused by the repeated wetting–drying cycles in the stone chamber, it is unclear to what extent it can cause the plaster to fall off the walls. To minimize the plaster deterioration and the salt movement, it is necessary to reduce evaporation inside the stone chamber.

sec.title: Computer modeling of climate inside the Tumulus
Object
sec.p: Figures 2 and 3 show the temporary conservation facilities connected to the front of the stone chamber, which was set up to maintain the environmental conditions. Soil and a waterproof sheet were used to cover the south chamber, except when investigation was being conducted inside the stone chamber. Based on the above-mentioned climatic data, the study analyzed the two-dimensional model shown in Figure 3. The model shows a north–south section with the surrounding earth mound. Figure 3(a) is the state prior to excavation, and Figure 3(b) refers to the state without any conservation measures, immediately after the excavation (called Case 0). When considering the effects of emergency preservation measures immediately after excavation, several cases were taken into account, as shown in Figure 3(c), such as the case that emergency protective facilities were installed to the south stone chamber (called Case 1); the use of 50 cm of soil to cover the south stone chamber in addition to Case 1 (called Case 2), and the use of a waterproof layer, set into the soil covering besides Case 2 (called Case 3). Case 3 was actually adopted, as later described in detail.

sec.p: The model uses climatic data collected by Nara Local Meteorological Observatories (Japan Meteorological Business Support Center, 2007) in 1972, including external temperature, air RH, global solar radiation, precipitation, and night radiation. sec.title: Material characterization used as input to the model
sec.p: The stone chamber of Takamatsuzuka Tumulus is 2.6 m long, 1 m wide, and 1.1 m high and consists of a single-layered tuff wall, approximately 0.6 m thick, which is surrounded by the earth mound comprising sandy clay loam. The measured value is used for equilibrium moisture content and the thermal conductivity (Ishizaki et al., 2006) of the mound surrounding the stone chamber, and moisture conductivity is derived from the measured equilibrium moisture content (Khalil and Ishizaki, 2007) and particle size distribution (Ishizaki et al., 2006) of the surrounding soil, according to the Arya–Paris model (Arya et al., 1999). The stone chamber is composed of tuff, and the equilibrium moisture content, thermal conductivity, and moisture conductivity of tuff are derived from reference values (Kitano et al., 1988; Kodai, 1984; Takahashi et al., 1999). Figures 7 to 10 show the thermal conductivity, equilibrium moisture content, moisture conductivity, and moisture conductivity (gas phase) related to the gradient of water chemical potential, respectively, of tuff and soil, and Figure 11 shows its moisture conductivity related to temperature gradient.

sec.title: Calculation method
sec.p: An explicit control volume method is used for the calculations. For the result before excavation, the annual cycle steady state will be discussed. For the calculation prior to excavation, the initial conditions of the model were determined by the annual cycle steady state on December 31 of the year prior to excavation; the calculation from January 1 to March 6 will be performed under modeling conditions shown in Figure 3(a). The calculation from March 6 to April 1 used modeling condition as shown in Figure 3(b). The calculation after April 1 was conducted according to Figure 12 (Case 3, as shown later). When comparing the effects of the various preservation methods, the calculated result for the third year after excavation began is discussed by regarding the annual cycle steady state on December 31 prior to excavation as the initial model condition. Figure 13 shows the outline of the calculation area and the boundary condition. Boundary conditions on the bare ground and inner surface of stone chamber refer to the third kind of boundary condition. At the bottom of the calculation area, boundary condition refers to the first kind of boundary condition (temperature is 14.6°C and water chemical potential is −7 J/kg). The stone chamber is considered to be closed because the time people enter the stone chamber for investigation is only 8 h every year (refer to the National Treasure Takamatsuzuka Tumulus Preservation and Maintenance, Agency of Cultural Affairs (1987)); the air exchange rate between the stone chamber and temporary shelter is assumed to be 0 air changes/h.

Only heat behavior is considered in the structure of the temporary shelter, and the structure of the temporary shelter is airtight.
Because the stone chamber is only opened four times per year (about 2 h at each instance), heat and moisture transfer associated with people working in the stone chamber is not considered here.

sec.title: Result and discussion
Comparison between measured and calculated values
sec.p: Both the analytical and measured values (Miura et al., 2005; National Treasure Takamatsuzuka Tumulus Preservation and Maintenance, Agency of Cultural Affairs, 1987) of indoor temperature from 1972 to 1973 are shown in Figure 14. The results show that the calculated annual average and annual amplitude calculation values of the indoor temperature are generally good agreement with the observed data, but there is slight phase difference between the two data sets. This is because, in actual excavation, only the part of the earth mound near to the south of the stone chamber was excavated, but the two-dimensional model assumes that the whole of the southern side of the stone chambers is excavated (Figure 3(b)), and the three-dimensional effect of actual excavated region is not able to be fully considered. It is thought that, despite the phase difference, the two-dimensional analytical model can reliably estimate the temperature inside the stone chamber. For humidity, after opening the stone chamber while investigating the site, the measured value is constantly kept at 95% RH or more, but the analytical result was calculated as 99%, shown in Figure 15, indicating that the model can also approximate the high humidity in the stone chamber. The following section discusses the various options for preservation measures by making use of the model.

sec.title: Discussion of the hygrothermal environment before and after excavation
sec.p: To evaluate the effect of preservation measures, one must know the environmental conditions for the protected objects. In this article, the periodic steady state environment in the stone chamber before excavation will be compared with environment after excavation (without any conservation measures). Furthermore, with setting the initial condition for calculation model as value on 31 December 1972, the analysis will be computed for 3 years until the environmen in the stone chamber is considered as the periodic steady state environment.

sec.title: Change of hygrothermal environment in stone chamber before and after excavation
sec.p: The comparison of hygrothermal environmental change before and after excavation (Case 0) is shown in Figures 16 and 17. The temperature in the stone chamber before excavation fluctuates within a small range and is 13.4°C ± 0.9°C. After excavation, the temperature fluctuation and the annual average temperature are increased to 14.7°C ± 7.4°C, close to the external environment (see Figure 16). While before excavation, RH (Figure 17) was near 100% all year round but, after excavation, it decreased to 96.6% in August and September, and stays at 99.3% in May and December.

caption.p: Comparison of air temperature in the stone chamber.
Comparison of relative air humidity in the stone chamber.

sec.title: Change of distribution of RH on the surface
sec.p: Figures 18 and 19 show the RH distribution on the interior surface of the stone chamber before and after it was excavated. Both figures show the RH distribution of the wall surface inside the chamber, in the direction from the corner of north ceiling shown in Figure 20, which is regarded as the starting point. While before excavation, the RH approached 100%, after excavation still exceeds 97% from winter to spring, but in summer, the humidity in corner of south wall and ceiling decreased to 84%. This is because the south side of the stone chamber is influenced by outdoor air. As temperature of the south wall of the stone chamber is higher than other parts during summer, there is some drying. Yet, when during winter the temperature in this corner is lower than at other locations, the wetting of the wall occurs.

caption.p: Comparison of relative humidity distribution on the surface inside chamber.
Comparison of relative humidity distribution on the surfaces inside the chamber after excavation with no conservation.
A diagram showing the positions of the surfaces inside the stone chamber.

sec.title: Increase of condensation on the surface of the stone chamber
sec.p: In this study, we estimate that condensation occurs when the water chemical potential reaches −5 J/kg. The “area of condensation” is an index that reflects the generation of dew condensation. This shows the ratio of the condensation area to that of the total indoor surface area. The relative area of condensation before and after excavation is shown in Figure 21. Before excavation, there was no condensation. After excavation, condensation from December to March reaches 15%, and 27.5% from the middle of June to October. Condensation occurred on 199 days during 1 year.

caption.p: Comparison of the area of daily average condensation on the chamber surface.

sec.title: Influence of environmental changes postexcavation on deterioration of mural paintings
sec.p: Before excavation, the RH in the stone chamber was high but extremely stable, so there was no wetting and drying cycles. It is thought that these stable conditions restricted fungal growth and the deterioration of the lime plaster layer.

Compared with the situation prior to excavation, the growth of microorganisms such as fungi has been promoted due to increased temperature within the stone chamber, and repeated wetting and drying cycles have worsened the situation. Consequently, the environmental conditions prior to excavation can be considered as the reference standard for developing postexcavation preservation measures.

sec.title: Discussion of effect of emergency preservation measures on the site after excavation
sec.p: In this section, we will discuss the individual emergency preservation measures taken immediately after excavation in order to clarify their actual effect.

sec.title: Analytical case of preservation measures
sec.p: After Takamatsuzuka Tumulus was excavated in 1972, a temporary shelter was set up to cover the stone chamber, and exposed parts of chamber were also covered with soil for protection. A polypropylene sheet was placed beneath the soil to prevent moisture infiltration. To examine the effects of these measures, the four following cases, shown in Figure 12, are discussed.

list-item.p: Case 1: Installation of a temporary shelter in the south stone chamber. To cover the excavated parts, a temporary timber-framed shelter with a plastic corrugated roof is set up in front of the south side of the stone chamber. This shelter is an outhouse 2.75 m in width, 7.5 m in length, and 4.5 m in height. The calculations only consider heat transfers on the ceiling and wall surfaces.

Case 2: The stone chamber is covered with soil and the temporary shelter is built. Because there is no accurate record of the thickness of this soil covering, it is assumed that the thickness of clay on the exposed part is 50 cm here.

Case 3: Installation of a waterproof layer within the soil covering. When covering the south stone chamber with soil, a waterproof layer is set into the soil to restrain evaporation. The position where the waterproof layer was installed is assumed as shown in Figure 12 because there are no records available. The thermal resistance of the waterproof layer is not considered in the calculation, and the water flux is treated as zero.
Case 4: No temporary shelter constructed in Case 2. The situation of only covering the site with soil will be considered, and the effect of this kind of conservation method is discussed.

sec.title: Influence of various conservation measures on hygrothermal environment in stone chamber
sec.p: Figures 22 and 23 show the annual fluctuation of the hygrothermal environment in the stone chamber when four kinds of conservation measures are considered. From Figure 22, the largest change of temperature within the stone chamber is in Case 1, with annual range of 5.8°C. From Cases 2 to 4, the change of temperature is controlled, and annual ranges are 2.7°C, 2.7°C, and 2.8°C, respectively. Cases 2 and 3 show the lowest maximum temperature and smallest annual temperature fluctuation, respectively. Moreover, comparison of Cases 2 and 3 shows that the waterproof layer has little influence on temperature. From the comparison between Cases 1 and 4, the more effective measure to control the rise of temperature in summer is to cover the structure with soil rather than construct a temporary shelter. From Figure 23, no matter what kinds of conservation measures are actually used, the annual change of humidity inside the stone chamber is small compared with the case of no conservation measures being used at all (Case 0: Figure 13), and the indoor humidity constantly exceeds 98%. From the viewpoint of fungi control, the most effective conservation measure of the analyzed cases is Case 3, and Case 2 (in which the waterproof layer is removed from Case 3).

caption.p: Comparison air temperature in the stone chamber: Cases 1–4.
Comparison the relative air humidity in the stone chamber: Cases 1–4.

sec.title: Influence of various conservation measures on RH on the surface of stone chamber
sec.p: Figure 24 compares the RH distribution on the surface of stone chamber for various conservation measures. In winter (left row), the various measures have little influence on the RH on the inner surface of the stone chamber. However, in summer (right row) there is a large variation. The minimum RH values from Cases 1 to 4 all occur near the corner between the south wall and the ceiling, with values of 87.6%, 98.0%, 98.8%, and 95.4%, respectively. Among these four scenarios, Case 3 shows the most effective conservation method. Moreover, comparison between Cases 2 and 3 indicates that the waterproof layer has some effect in restricting the decrease in humidity. From the comparison between Cases 1 and 4, it can be seen that, Case 4 have more effect on preventing dryness of the stone chamber than Case 1.

caption.p: Comparison of relative humidity distribution on the surface inside chamber: (a) Case 1, (b) Case 2, (c) Case 3, and (d) Case 4.

sec.title: Influence of conservation measures on average daily area of surface condensation
sec.p: Figure 25 compares the area of condensation when various conservation measures are used. In winter, although Case 1 shows the largest area of condensation, the difference between the situation without any preservation measures (Case 0: Figure 21) and that with a temporary shelter (Case 1) is small, indicating that the temporary shelter has less influence on the area affected by condensation. In Cases 2–4, the condensation is lower than in Cases 0 and 1, because Cases 2–4 are all covered by soil, which has a great influence in controlling the occurrence of condensation. Moreover, Case 4 shows reduced area of dew condensation compared with Case 2.

caption.p: Comparison of average daily area of condensation on interior surfaces.

sec.p: This is because the moisture content of stone materials and its covering soil is reduced in Case 4 when the absolute humidity of the outside air is lower than that inside the temporary shelter, and there is a large amount of evaporation from covering soil. In summer, the condensation in Case 1 occurs earlier than in Cases 2–4, and its value is a smaller than in Cases 2–4. Irrespective of the preservation measures adopted, condensation occurs constantly throughout the summer, on the north side of the chamber, so it appears that none of the discussed preservation method would eliminate the condensation in summer. The annual number of days of condensation for Cases 1–4 was 217, 193, 200, and 120, respectively. From the perspective of controlling condensation, none of these scenarios provides an environment appropriate for conservation of the murals.

sec.title: Integrated evaluation of preservation methods to degradation of mural painting
sec.p: This section evaluates the combined effect of integrated preservation methods. If temporary shelter facilities are installed on the south of the chamber (Case 1), the highest temperature inside the chamber is 1.6°C lower than that in the case with no protection (Case 0), but the effect in controlling dryness and condensation of the surface is limited. When the exposed part of the chamber is covered by soil, the highest temperature inside the chamber is 5.4°C lower than that in the case 0, and there is a greater effect in controlling the dryness of the interior surface of the chamber. In addition, if a waterproof layer is prepared beneath the soil cover, there will be a slight effect in controlling the humidity in the chamber, which can be considered almost equivalent to the protection provided by Case 2. Of the emergency preservation measures discussed, irrespective of the existence of a waterproof layer, the use of soil as provisional covering of the part exposed to the open air results in the best conditions. The measures adopted in Case 3 are similar with the measures that were actually performed in Takamatsuzuka Tumulus, and it is thought to be the most effective method from the viewpoint of inhibiting fungi growth and preventing dry exfoliation of the lime plaster. However, although several emergency preservation measures are discussed here, none provides more beneficial effects on restraining condensation both on the north wall and nearby floor during summer. Because use of thermal insulation as the conservation measure might also be effective to suppress temperature variation and temperature distribution in the stone chamber, we will investigate the effect of thermal insulation in next step research.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article developed a numerical model of Takamatsuzuka Tumulus before and after excavation, based on the changed shape of the tumulus. The predicted air temperature values in the stone chamber by the model were generally good agreement with the values observed. Finally, based on the relationship between hygrothermal environment in the chamber and deterioration of mural paintings, the effects of emergency preservation measures were quantitatively analyzed by means of numerical simulation, and an improved method of evaluating the effects of emergency preservation measures was established. The main findings are as follows:

list-item.p: Prior to excavation, the annual temperature variation inside the stone chamber was small, RH was nearly 100% throughout the year, and cycles of drying and condensation on the inner surface of the stone chamber were very infrequent.

The method of covering the exposed surface of the stone chamber with a certain thickness of soil is more effective in restricting the temperature rise in the stone chamber and drying of the interior surface.

The preservation options examined in this case study do not inhibit the high humidity of the north wall near the floor and the occurrence of dew condensation in summer. It is therefore necessary to consider other measures to control the occurrence of dew condensation during this period.
